componenttext: Simeon, good morning. If you look at Q1 so far, sequentially, we've seen some progress, but it is not up to what our expeditions are right now. We started out flat. We're actually in a period now where we're going up against our strongest comps from last year. So we are seeing some movement. We expect more. We have a plan that we intend to execute throughout the year. So we're not sitting back hoping for the weather to change. We're executing fundamental execution issues that we think will affect our business really around the availability in service areas. So early on, really a premature call. Again, we're only a period or so into the year, but we have every expectation that we're going to begin to get them up to our expectations.

componenttext: Okay. And I'll ask my follow-up, and just a clarification on that, is next question. The improvement you're seeing in --  and you said flat, but it's not up to your expectations. Is that weather markets getting better? Or did you see maybe something that as the margin and execution gets better? Anything given its capacity, how it's set up geographically, your ability to service the entire store base?

componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll start with the sales, Simeon, and say that just broadly, again, we're seeing obviously pockets of strength and pockets of weakness as we always do. So there always maybe some variability geographically. We're broadly still not where we wanted to
componenttext: Yes. I'll start with the sales, Simeon, and say that just broadly, again, we're seeing obviously pockets of strength and pockets of weakness as we always do. So there always maybe some variability geographically. We're broadly still not where we wanted to be, still we're working on improving it overall. From a supply chain standpoint, the biggest change we've seen so far, and we've mentioned this is, obviously, we have 1,300 stores now from Advance that are on multi-day delivery, and we've made changes to the upgrades to the AAP network in terms of DCs. We've also put capacity adjustments in for some of the CARQUEST distribution centers as well.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's going to be about bridging the margin from the 10.2% that you achieved in last year to the 12% in '16, so you're going to need about 180 basis points of expansion. It sounds like you're going to get 100 from the cost-reduction initiatives, another 50
componenttext: It's going to be about bridging the margin from the 10.2% that you achieved in last year to the 12% in '16, so you're going to need about 180 basis points of expansion. It sounds like you're going to get 100 from the cost-reduction initiatives, another 50 from the synergy realization. And then are we to assume the last portion is from gross margin expansion? And how visible is the SG&A improvement that you're expecting for 2016? So if your sales fall short of your expectation, what's the sensitivity to your margin if that happens?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, good morning. Obviously, our plan for 12%, which we recognize, were clearly improving mode on. So it requires a combination of working the cost lever, working gross margin, including there's a leverage component to it as well. We've gone to
componenttext: Yes, Michael, good morning. Obviously, our plan for 12%, which we recognize, were clearly improving mode on. So it requires a combination of working the cost lever, working gross margin, including there's a leverage component to it as well. We've gone to great efforts to work hard on the cost components of this, and we're working equally or doubly hard on sales right now. Cost, we can control right away. So we've made some improvements, and you're right, we're going to take a big chunk out of our cost structure, and we're going to continue to look for ways and begin to find more and more of it. So we're not stopping at 100 basis points or stopping at any one fixed number. We keep looking to find more and more cost to take out to streamline this operation, build efficiency and really, frankly, limit the amount of workload that get -- sent down to our stores. So we will make adjustments on a lower comp and that in fact is what happens. We do clearly have expectations around leverage as part of this, about 12%.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And George, it sounds like it's part of the margin expectations, you are anticipating some benefit from a change in the store operating model and the pilot of the change in store compensation model. What have you seen already from those tests? And how qui
componenttext: And George, it sounds like it's part of the margin expectations, you are anticipating some benefit from a change in the store operating model and the pilot of the change in store compensation model. What have you seen already from those tests? And how quickly do you expect that you will be able to roll them out?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: From a store operating model standpoint, Michael, we are beginning to see some change, especially from the empowerment initiatives. So I think one of the biggest themes that we are working on right now is a quick move towards field-centricity. We recogniz
componenttext: From a store operating model standpoint, Michael, we are beginning to see some change, especially from the empowerment initiatives. So I think one of the biggest themes that we are working on right now is a quick move towards field-centricity. We recognize that we own very, very local businesses and they're all unique in their own way. We feel that we can get things 90%-plus right out of the Support Center, but we're empowering our teams to take at the right -- the rest of the way to 100%. So they now have more and more autonomy over adding SKUs to their assortment, adding more product to the supply chain system, we think that will have some of the most immediate benefits. The single selling model is -- we're in sustained mode on that one. The team is becoming more and more comfortable with it. And we believe that, fundamentally, it's the right thing to do, to serve all customers that walk in or call our stores. And as a business that's been quite now spoken about beig commercial first, everyone needs to be willing and able to pick up the telephone and help a commercial customer or hop in a truck and make a delivery. So we are pleased with that aspect of it. The compensation pilot is just that. It's a pilot in a limited amount of stores that is not having much impact nor is it intended to right now across the entire chain of stores, it's a learning event for us right now. And my focus is to get the empowerment to the field that allows for a true sense of business ownership before putting in a compensation system that rewards business ownership.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Basham of Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Basham of Wedbush Securities.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow-up on some of the earlier questions to make sure I understand your bridge from where you're running right now of comp store sales wise to low single digits. In terms of the largest drivers of that improvement, does it have to do with how yo
componenttext: Just to follow-up on some of the earlier questions to make sure I understand your bridge from where you're running right now of comp store sales wise to low single digits. In terms of the largest drivers of that improvement, does it have to do with how you're going about changing the SKU availability to the stores? Or there are other support initiatives that you have that you think will be the key drivers here?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Seth. It's a combination of both. So if you ask us the SKU availability, we're going to absolutely say yes to that question every time. Our business fundamentally is quite simple. A customer asks us, if we have the part, and can we get it to
componenttext: Good morning, Seth. It's a combination of both. So if you ask us the SKU availability, we're going to absolutely say yes to that question every time. Our business fundamentally is quite simple. A customer asks us, if we have the part, and can we get it to him quickly? And that is how we operate and that's how we run and that's how we will drive comps over time. So yes, to having the part is absolutely critical for us and getting availability right, and we feel we've made some good progress on that, is absolutely job won for us. That being said, there are other initiatives that have an impact on comp sales during the course of the year. Certainly, our consolidation of CARQUEST stores will impact our comp sales. The Speed Perks program at 10 million numbers will impact our comp sales. More investments in inventory and hubs will affect our comp stores. And the move to multi-day delivery will affect comp sales as well. So we had a waterfall of activities that we built out that we think will drive comp sales methodically, but clearly, it starts from availability.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And just a follow-up to that. If you think about your progression in comps in 2015 and the deterioration over the year, when you diagnose that, how much of it is due to lost customers on the commercial side? And where do you think your ability
componenttext: Okay, good. And just a follow-up to that. If you think about your progression in comps in 2015 and the deterioration over the year, when you diagnose that, how much of it is due to lost customers on the commercial side? And where do you think your ability is to win back those lost customers?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I probably make a distinction, Seth, and say that it's lost business on the commercial side as opposed to lost customers on the commercial side. If we lose some, of course, we did, we know that. But we point to categories like our strength and brake
componenttext: Well, I probably make a distinction, Seth, and say that it's lost business on the commercial side as opposed to lost customers on the commercial side. If we lose some, of course, we did, we know that. But we point to categories like our strength and brakes, as indicated, that we still have a healthy base of commercial customers who are still buying from us. We need to sell them the entire car. So going back and just trying to reestablish connections with customers is difficult, but trying to expand your base of business with existing customers is a more attainable objective certainly.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scot Ciccarelli of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scot Ciccarelli of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So last quarter, you guys referred to roughly 10% of your sales base comping down over 10%. That was the 120 basis point drag you referenced. And I think the suggestion was those stores were undergoing significant changes, but you've also referred to stor
componenttext: So last quarter, you guys referred to roughly 10% of your sales base comping down over 10%. That was the 120 basis point drag you referenced. And I think the suggestion was those stores were undergoing significant changes, but you've also referred to stores and markets that comp in the mid upper single-digits, where they've undergone all the changes and the businesses had a chance to settle into a natural rhythm. I guess what I'm curious about is better understanding the cadence of sales changes in a specific market. In other words, what happens to comps when the changes first start? How long do these disruptions last? And then when do you start to see the improvements? And I know that there is a bunch of different items that happen obviously along the way.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Scot. Good morning. Let me try to take that in sequence. I think if you look at, first of all, our comments around what you're describing our outlier stores, which was a group of stores that disproportionately affected our sales miss, a coupl
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Scot. Good morning. Let me try to take that in sequence. I think if you look at, first of all, our comments around what you're describing our outlier stores, which was a group of stores that disproportionately affected our sales miss, a couple of actions there. #1, as we previously mentioned and mentioned in the script, we closed some stores during the course of the fourth quarter. You can fully expect that they were among those bottom 10% performers. So that's a small group of stores and that's not the entire difference. We also are moving into a period right now where we're currently executing accelerated consolidations of poor performing stores. So in this case, specific CARQUEST stores that were not meeting our expectations that we've now begun to consolidate into Advance Auto Part stores and that will stall for another tranche of the stores. There are still outlier stores and there will be. So our field teams continue to work on the performance of some of our outliers. As you look at the consolidation or the market conversions and look at results, we're generally pleased, and we're pretty much pleased across the board. So that number, that initial number that you referred to was clearly inflated due to the CARQUEST conversions. So once the market begins to undergo conversion there is, as you'd expect, a negative sales impact. And it really lasts for anywhere from 5 to 6 weeks. So we see these created about 1 month to 1.5 months when there's actually physical construction going on in the stores, team members are changing, parts are changing in some cases, that we see comps go down and then we see it ramp back up. And our effort has been to take that time for it and compress it as much as possible, and we have. So in the early consolidations, it was a longer period of time. So we've seen that narrow down pretty nicely over time to the point where -- and obviously, we will work to continue to improve that to be shorter and shorter. That's about 5 to 6 weeks that there's a negative impact and then the store begins to emerge with better results. And that generally shows up in the form of double-digit comps [indiscernible] in consolidations and anywhere from single, mid-single to high single up to double-digit comps in our conversion stores.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so are there any -- George, are there any markets where you've done the conversion, but haven't seen that kind of result?
componenttext: And so are there any -- George, are there any markets where you've done the conversion, but haven't seen that kind of result?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of all the conversions that we've done, there are 1, maybe 2 markets where it's been strictly limited to just conversion. Not consolidating 2 boxes, but just conversion that we've seen flattish results, and we're working to improve. By and large, the over
componenttext: Of all the conversions that we've done, there are 1, maybe 2 markets where it's been strictly limited to just conversion. Not consolidating 2 boxes, but just conversion that we've seen flattish results, and we're working to improve. By and large, the overall majority of the markets have had the kind of results that we wanted.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Understood. And then secondly, payables to inventory ratio, it's obviously a huge cash flow driver for your industry. You guys are still performing well below your direct peers. What's the right way to think about that kind of ratio going forward
componenttext: Got you. Understood. And then secondly, payables to inventory ratio, it's obviously a huge cash flow driver for your industry. You guys are still performing well below your direct peers. What's the right way to think about that kind of ratio going forward and the impact on the cash flow?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, we obviously want to work to continue to drive our AP ratio. We will focus on taking inventory out. We do have some specific vendor focuses. So as you look at our AP ratio, you look at our base of business, we have a fairly targeted list of tho
componenttext: Yes. Look, we obviously want to work to continue to drive our AP ratio. We will focus on taking inventory out. We do have some specific vendor focuses. So as you look at our AP ratio, you look at our base of business, we have a fairly targeted list of those that we're negotiating with to make some changes on AP ratio. At the same time, we're being very clear that availability is job 1. So we don't want to send mixed signals to our team, we've got to be in stock. We've got to have the parts that the customer wants when they want it.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Wewer of Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Wewer of Raymond James.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, on the sales lift in the conversion stores, I guess you're calling out 5% to 12% increases. Is that primarily the do-it-yourself revenues kicking in with the availability of the Advance do-it-yourself assortment in those CARQUEST stores? Or is it
componenttext: George, on the sales lift in the conversion stores, I guess you're calling out 5% to 12% increases. Is that primarily the do-it-yourself revenues kicking in with the availability of the Advance do-it-yourself assortment in those CARQUEST stores? Or is it the commercial revenues picking up?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a combination of both. So when we talk about a conversion store, we're simply rebranding. We're going into CARQUEST. We're making it an Advance Auto Part store. We are enhancing the sales floor in those cases. So we do see and we do expect to se
componenttext: Yes, it's a combination of both. So when we talk about a conversion store, we're simply rebranding. We're going into CARQUEST. We're making it an Advance Auto Part store. We are enhancing the sales floor in those cases. So we do see and we do expect to see a DIY lift in those stores and we have been seeing it. That said, that brings an additional commercial business as well, so we've been pleased on both fronts, which you're right that as we convert stores, our real expectations are around trying to bring a little bit of DIY to a store that's historically not having.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the consolidation, sorry, you still saying 70% to 80% of the commercial business in that consolidated store transferring to the remaining Advance store?
componenttext: And on the consolidation, sorry, you still saying 70% to 80% of the commercial business in that consolidated store transferring to the remaining Advance store?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We are again 70% is closer to the right number.
componenttext: Yes. We are again 70% is closer to the right number.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And of the 325 to 350 consolidations and conversions for this year, how does that split out between the 2? I know the economics are very different between a consolidation and a conversion, but so how will that split out between those 2 types of projects?
componenttext: And of the 325 to 350 consolidations and conversions for this year, how does that split out between the 2? I know the economics are very different between a consolidation and a conversion, but so how will that split out between those 2 types of projects?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roughly 50-50.
componenttext: Roughly 50-50.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: 50-50. And then the last question I have. On the expense reduction goal of 100 basis points, and then if you assume that 50 basis points of the synergies, maybe that flows into expenses as well, that would imply that expense dollars are roughly flat, it l
componenttext: 50-50. And then the last question I have. On the expense reduction goal of 100 basis points, and then if you assume that 50 basis points of the synergies, maybe that flows into expenses as well, that would imply that expense dollars are roughly flat, it looks like, in 2016 compared to '15 adjusting for the 53rd week? How much of those have already been achieved through closing the 80 underperforming stores, through the consolidations of the corporate office? How much of that expense savings already have been achieved? And how much of it has yet to be achieved?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dollars were actually down, so not flat, but down to last year, and we continued to accelerate on that and look for more opportunities. And I want to be clear, we won't do things that are cutting the sales muscle. So when we talk about SG&A, we're primari
componenttext: Dollars were actually down, so not flat, but down to last year, and we continued to accelerate on that and look for more opportunities. And I want to be clear, we won't do things that are cutting the sales muscle. So when we talk about SG&A, we're primarily talking about G&A, and we continue to look for more and more opportunities. If we made substantial progress, dollars will be down.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the biggest variable on achieving the 12% EBIT rate, well, then how do you achieve that really is a function of whether or not the comps are flat or maybe up 2%, and then, to a lesser extent, whether or not you can deliver on the gross margin gain? It
componenttext: So the biggest variable on achieving the 12% EBIT rate, well, then how do you achieve that really is a function of whether or not the comps are flat or maybe up 2%, and then, to a lesser extent, whether or not you can deliver on the gross margin gain? It sounds like the cost reduction effort that's -- there's really -- there's no way that you can miss on that?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look. We know the size of the improvement that it represents 10% to a 12%, and it certainly would be aided quite a bit by the top line that we expect. So the leverage portion of this is important, but we've clearly over indexed on the expense side.
componenttext: Yes, look. We know the size of the improvement that it represents 10% to a 12%, and it certainly would be aided quite a bit by the top line that we expect. So the leverage portion of this is important, but we've clearly over indexed on the expense side.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Greg Melich of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Greg Melich of Evercore ISI.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to make sure I understood the charges Mike that you outlined and sort of what's incremental and what was in the plan and what I should compare that to? So the incremental $75 million to $90 million of charges, would that compare to that what was
componenttext: I wanted to make sure I understood the charges Mike that you outlined and sort of what's incremental and what was in the plan and what I should compare that to? So the incremental $75 million to $90 million of charges, would that compare to that what was the $127 million in 2015 and $82 million in 2014?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Greg, we gave an outlook of $75 million to $90 million. And $65 million to $75 million of that would be comparable to the last year portion, and those relate to the market conversions and the IT projects around the catalog and the store systems. S
componenttext: Yes. So Greg, we gave an outlook of $75 million to $90 million. And $65 million to $75 million of that would be comparable to the last year portion, and those relate to the market conversions and the IT projects around the catalog and the store systems. So those are primarily the driver as we think in 2016, and those are comparable to the onetime costs we were looking last year. And then the $10 million to $15 million is our supply optimization work that really gets going this year. And that -- a big driver of that is the Sutton DC that we're going to be closing down this year.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I did -- my follow-up will be going back to the sales trend, George, which is, do you have a -- what really happened with DIY versus do it for me in the quarter? You gave some nice category issues in some of the regions. But if you look at bas
componenttext: Got it. And I did -- my follow-up will be going back to the sales trend, George, which is, do you have a -- what really happened with DIY versus do it for me in the quarter? You gave some nice category issues in some of the regions. But if you look at basically what were the 2 sides of the business? And what were the sales, that we want to cut it?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Really, we have softness in both sides of the business. And when we talk about whether which we don't like talking, that clearly represents more of an impact on DIY, and specifically, a category like batteries. So we had some great strength that we w
componenttext: Yes. Really, we have softness in both sides of the business. And when we talk about whether which we don't like talking, that clearly represents more of an impact on DIY, and specifically, a category like batteries. So we had some great strength that we went up against in batteries and we didn't see the cold this time around. And that just based on that 1 line alone has a pretty significant impact on the DIY business, but it was both parts weather on the DIY side.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mike, just a follow-up to the previous one. Just do you have an EPS range guidance that falls out of this? I mean, if you just take the margin and the comp, you get to something like $9.50, at least that's my back in the envelope math. Was I missing s
componenttext: And Mike, just a follow-up to the previous one. Just do you have an EPS range guidance that falls out of this? I mean, if you just take the margin and the comp, you get to something like $9.50, at least that's my back in the envelope math. Was I missing something there?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'm not going to comment on that, Greg. But what I will tell you is, we gave today -- we gave in the release our assumptions and they reflect the most important outcomes that we're focused on this year, which is improving our profitability and imp
componenttext: Yes. So I'm not going to comment on that, Greg. But what I will tell you is, we gave today -- we gave in the release our assumptions and they reflect the most important outcomes that we're focused on this year, which is improving our profitability and improving our sales, and we remain committed to our 12% target. Given the variability in the range of our comps and trying to predict where we'll fall in that range and as we are building momentum, and also, the structural moves that we're going to continue to do to improve to move to a more field-centric and localized business, we've chose not to try to predict an outlook range. But we think we've given you the assumptions that reflect the outcomes that we're expecting this year.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tony Cristello of BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tony Cristello of BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first part is, it's bigger picture. You talk about the field-centric approach and 2 of the categories being availability and infrastructure. And what I'm wondering is, how much does 2016 cover for those 2 buckets versus how much will be left to get yo
componenttext: The first part is, it's bigger picture. You talk about the field-centric approach and 2 of the categories being availability and infrastructure. And what I'm wondering is, how much does 2016 cover for those 2 buckets versus how much will be left to get you where you really want to be in '17 and '18? And I'm just trying to understand, is this a shift in terms of trajectory of where you were taking the business? And is it now another 2 or 3 years to get you where you need to be?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Tony, it's George. I would call it a stair-step approach. I mean, we've been talking about our customer, our field-centricity for well over 18 months now. We've just accelerated our pace pretty substantially. So I would not look at this as a multiyear
componenttext: No. Tony, it's George. I would call it a stair-step approach. I mean, we've been talking about our customer, our field-centricity for well over 18 months now. We've just accelerated our pace pretty substantially. So I would not look at this as a multiyear rebuilding process, but I would look at it as an evolution that's already begun and that we've taken very substantial steps toward accelerating in the past quarter. So it really is -- I mean, we are not trying to flip how we buy or inventory merchandise. We are simply giving our team in the field an ability to take the limited portion based on what they see as specific need for their customers and get it right. And we just don't feel like 5,300 times over, we can have the level of exactitude out of this office that reflects what's happening in the field, and we want to empower our field team to make -- to put in those difference makers to get it or may be 90% to 100% correct. So hyper local business, especially for commercial, and we feel like the team needs to have a say on how they're assorted, what the quantities look like because they know changes to their business faster than our systems are able to detect them.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on that, so it sounds like the systems going into next year should be in place for what you need?
componenttext: And then on that, so it sounds like the systems going into next year should be in place for what you need?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think the systems are very quickly falling into place right now. So we are moving very, very fast on this. Again, we do not look at this as a multiyear project. We look at this as a shift in some decision rights. We look at this as being a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think the systems are very quickly falling into place right now. So we are moving very, very fast on this. Again, we do not look at this as a multiyear project. We look at this as a shift in some decision rights. We look at this as being a more effective listening organization. And we think it properly orients around our whole team where all it matters most, which is our customer and our store teams.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess the one follow-up here is on the infrastructure. Do you have an update on how you would see this infrastructure best in place to meet the needs of fulfilling an availability? I mean, what changes still remain in order to get you the
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess the one follow-up here is on the infrastructure. Do you have an update on how you would see this infrastructure best in place to meet the needs of fulfilling an availability? I mean, what changes still remain in order to get you the fill rates that you're still not at?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tony, I mean, I think if you look at multi-day delivery, for instance, we said, I think, that we would try to tailor that to our specific customer's needs. And there is a formula in every market that we think is the right outcome that's best to serve
componenttext: Yes. Tony, I mean, I think if you look at multi-day delivery, for instance, we said, I think, that we would try to tailor that to our specific customer's needs. And there is a formula in every market that we think is the right outcome that's best to serve our customer. That affects -- that may be 5X delivery, that could be 3x delivery. That may be 5 HUB runs a day, that may be 7 HUB runs a day. That may be an in-market Super HUB, may not be. So it is just -- it is calibrating our market needs to the needs of the customers, the pace of the commercial business and making sure that it's right. So we still continue to work through that formula. We feel great about some markets and we clearly recognize we have opportunities in other markets.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But you have enough distribution capacity in place, it's just reworking that? Or do you still think you're going to need to be adding as we move forward?
componenttext: Okay. But you have enough distribution capacity in place, it's just reworking that? Or do you still think you're going to need to be adding as we move forward?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have the infrastructure in place. We'll upgrade 3 DCs in 2016. So we'll begin to add further capacity to those facilities. We'll also add 7 new Super HUBs in 2016. So we'll look and we'll find those market opportunities where they exist, and we'll make
componenttext: We have the infrastructure in place. We'll upgrade 3 DCs in 2016. So we'll begin to add further capacity to those facilities. We'll also add 7 new Super HUBs in 2016. So we'll look and we'll find those market opportunities where they exist, and we'll make those changes, but largely, we feel we have the infrastructure in place.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Fassler of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is just to quantify the number of stores that are in that, the conversion markets that are generating those mid-single-digit to high-single digit increases, and then just to quantify the number of stores that you would expect to enter a
componenttext: My first question is just to quantify the number of stores that are in that, the conversion markets that are generating those mid-single-digit to high-single digit increases, and then just to quantify the number of stores that you would expect to enter a similar stage of integration, [indiscernible]from a similar stage of integration in '16.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, we touched roughly 1/3 of our stores with the conversion consolidation relocation activity. So about 1/3 of the CARQUEST stores that needed to be addressed. We'll hit 350 more this year. And as we've -- as I mentioned earlier, about a 50-50 split be

We'll hit 350 more this year. headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question, just to kind of big picture philosophically. You seem to have 2 big efforts happening simultaneously. The first is the conversion of the CARQUEST chain and the kind of the upgrading of execution on a number of levels, an
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question, just to kind of big picture philosophically. You seem to have 2 big efforts happening simultaneously. The first is the conversion of the CARQUEST chain and the kind of the upgrading of execution on a number of levels, and the second is an effort to take out costs. Now understanding that you've got an SG&A ratio opportunity versus some of your peers, it seems like those 2 efforts are somewhat or can be somewhat an opposition. It's certainly much harder to improve execution and generate top line as you are taking costs out of the business. Is there a thought to focusing on the operational improvement to stabilize the top line prior to accelerating those cost reductions?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, there was an effort to separate the taking cost off from affecting the top line, so we're looking very much at non-customer focused activities. So take things like indirect procurement, areas of the business like that, looking at the store portfolio
componenttext: Matt, there was an effort to separate the taking cost off from affecting the top line, so we're looking very much at non-customer focused activities. So take things like indirect procurement, areas of the business like that, looking at the store portfolio, as we've done, take out ineffective assets along the way. We are laser-focused on improving top line performance, that is absolutely job 1. And we feel that, that we have our field team on the point for that. Field team drives the sales improvement and the corporate team is here to support. On the cost outside, we've gone more towards G&A and the corporate team has taken more of a lead in that activity. So we think that they're compatible. We absolutely will not let ourselves cutting the muscle that affects sales ability.
