headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth Basham from Wedbush. My question is on the store labor model. What have you observed over the 6 months, Tom, on a labor model? And how do you change it going forward? A lot of shifting roles and responsibilities between DIY, DIFM and the incentive st
componenttext: Seth Basham from Wedbush. My question is on the store labor model. What have you observed over the 6 months, Tom, on a labor model? And how do you change it going forward? A lot of shifting roles and responsibilities between DIY, DIFM and the incentive structure obviously has been up for consideration. Can you give us some observations?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Seth. I mean, I think, obviously we made some adjustments to our labor model in the latter part of last year. And I think we may have rushed a little bit in terms of the execution of that, which is an opportunity for us going forward. I mean
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Seth. I mean, I think, obviously we made some adjustments to our labor model in the latter part of last year. And I think we may have rushed a little bit in terms of the execution of that, which is an opportunity for us going forward. I mean, we want to make sure -- I mean, when you're talking about something as important as your store labor, which faces customers, it requires a tremendous amount of analytics upfront, rigorous testing, proven methodologies, then you roll it out. So what I observed was we weren't really approaching it that way. And so we had to sort of reverse course on some of the things that we did. And early on, it's been very well received by our field organization. You have to listen to what our region vice presidents, our district managers, our general managers in the stores are telling us. And as I went around, I mean, I tried to spend as much time in the stores as I can, and I do take a lot of notes and I listen to them when they tell me this is not driving my comps, it's -- it gives you the illusion of profitability because you're reducing cost and you're really just getting customers angry and they don't come back to your store. And then it's just a bit of a vicious circle.
So we've been very thoughtful about our labor model. I think we've made a lot of progress on better aligning our hours to the demand, both on the DIY side and on the commercial side, and we'll continue to do that. We've got to make sure that we can service the customer with all of the things that they want, whether it's parking lot services or delivery frequency or when they want the part. We've got to have the labor there to fulfill the demand, and we've made pretty significant changes, I would say, in how we're approaching that.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just as a follow-up, if there are more changes to come, what's the time line for them? Are we talking about another year? Or are we pretty much at status quo?
componenttext: That's helpful. And just as a follow-up, if there are more changes to come, what's the time line for them? Are we talking about another year? Or are we pretty much at status quo?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016

componenttext: For labor particularly? Yes, no, I mean, we're -- the changes that we've initiated are fairly positive right now on labor. We're going to continue to refine them. We certainly reserve the right to do better, but I'm pleased with the results that we've had so far on our labor model.

componenttext: Yes, that's a similar question -- Jack, was it? Yes -- to what we had earlier. We basically stepped back on the original goals that were outlined and integrated them into the broader strategic business plan. We're very comfortable with the 5-year outlook, and we're going to do it in a way -- the full integration in a way that's not disruptive. And I want to make sure that as we bring the supply chains together, as we integrate the systems and do all the things that were part of that plan, that we do it in a way that's going to be flawlessly executed. So that time line is different than we originally communicated. The new time line is different.

componenttext: Bret Jordan of Jefferies, quick follow-up. On the AP to inventory, Tom, you were saying you thought you're going to reach your peers' levels. componenttext: Yes, I think you do -- you hit the nail right on the head. You have to adjust for the dynamic of Worldpac on that. So then it starts to get into how much is the mix of Worldpac. And as we're talking on the 5-year window, it's at 100, it's at 90. At this point in time, we're just swagging. So -- but we want to get the industry leaded, obviously adjusting for the Worldpac payables dynamic.

componenttext: It's Adam Liebhoff from Loomis, Sayles. Just getting back to the cash flow question. So if you have more cash than you need, I guess, the long-winded way of getting the question is how do I think about -- or how are your repurchases paired against your view of intrinsic value of the stock?

componenttext: I think we're weighing into a very hypothetical question in terms of value of the stock versus potential repurchases. Clearly, I gave you the order. But I don't want to get into speculation of where the stock value is in terms of repurchases.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the supply chain because it does feel like the Holy Grail for this industry to make sure you have the parts when and where you need them. I had always had the impression that the legacy AAP DCs maybe weren't perfect. That's kind of why
componenttext: Just a question on the supply chain because it does feel like the Holy Grail for this industry to make sure you have the parts when and where you need them. I had always had the impression that the legacy AAP DCs maybe weren't perfect. That's kind of why you built Remington sort of as a test, but that they weren't perfect for the professional customer. Maybe the Carquest, they had a lot of DCs, but they also were a little bit inefficient or maybe not perfect for the professional customer. Do you -- it sounds like you're happy with the supply chain as it is and you can kind of make it work. But if you had to redo the system, would you do it differently?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's obviously a very difficult question. I mean, we did greenfield the solution. We looked at what a greenfield solution would look like. But then, of course, you have to overlay. I've got capital in the ground today with this asset base and the -- the
componenttext: That's obviously a very difficult question. I mean, we did greenfield the solution. We looked at what a greenfield solution would look like. But then, of course, you have to overlay. I've got capital in the ground today with this asset base and the -- the piloting did reveal that there was more elegant ways to get the right part in the right place at the right time than perhaps we'd looked at in the past. And knowing what we have, our distribution center network, our super hubs, our hubs, our store network, we have a great asset base. I just want to kind of reinforce that just utilizing that asset base differently than we've used it in the past is how we're thinking about it. So we'll continue to look for opportunities to improve it over time, but we feel great about the asset base that we have. We do feel there's an opportunity to streamline, as I mentioned earlier. But how will we have done it differently? That's a tough question. I do know what we have today is fantastic, and Bob is all over it as it pertains to professional customers. He's going to be tapping into every single one of those distribution centers to get parts closer to the customer, and we're excited about the streamlining because that's going to bring parts closer to the customer just in and of itself.

componenttext: Mike Montani from Evercore ISI. componenttext: Okay. Well, we're not going to break out the DIFM-DIY split. I can tell you that we did improve proportionately in both of them. Professional has been outperforming DIY for us, and it outperformed in the quarter. So we're going to continue to drive at both of those business very, very differently. And I missed your second question.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of the mid-single-digit comp that was longer term, maybe can you help us build to that in terms of volume versus pricing?
componenttext: Just in terms of the mid-single-digit comp that was longer term, maybe can you help us build to that in terms of volume versus pricing?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we're really focused on unit growth. I mean, A [ph] parts, we measure it. I want to know units. Pricing is nice, but we want to grow our business by getting more customers. We want those customers to buy more parts from us over the course of
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we're really focused on unit growth. I mean, A [ph] parts, we measure it. I want to know units. Pricing is nice, but we want to grow our business by getting more customers. We want those customers to buy more parts from us over the course of 52 weeks, over the course of 5 years. So making sure that we -- on the professional side, as Bob indicated, we've got a great lineup, a high-quality parts lineup. We think we've got a very strong lineup of parts there. We've got to deliver them at the time we promised to our customer, but we want them to buy more individual units from us. And that's why Bob and I have been spending a tremendous amount of time with our customers to really figure that part out, so you'll see us very focused on unit growth. Ultimately, we're going to look at pricing, but we're going to do it smartly. We're not going to take pricing so that we start losing customers. So the idea is to drive more customers and have more customers buy more parts from us.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just the DIY versus DIFM, do you need DIY to be up low single digit to get to the mid-singles? Or can you do it even if it's flat?
componenttext: And then just the DIY versus DIFM, do you need DIY to be up low single digit to get to the mid-singles? Or can you do it even if it's flat?

componenttextpreview: Yes, no, professional's going to carry the load. I think you probably know about 60% of our business is professional today. The category is growing at a disproportionate rate. We expect that will grow -- will outperform the industry, so you can do the mat
componenttext: Yes, no, professional's going to carry the load. I think you probably know about 60% of our business is professional today. The category is growing at a disproportionate rate. We expect that will grow -- will outperform the industry, so you can do the math. We're calling kind of 3, 4, 5 something like that for professional at the industry level. So for us to gain share, as Bob indicated, we have to be higher than that and that's the goal.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt Fassler from Goldman Sachs with a quick follow-up. I'm curious, now that each of you has a few months -- weeks to months at your respective roles, what kind of tools you have to understand market share trends. And with that in mind, as you entered th
componenttext: Matt Fassler from Goldman Sachs with a quick follow-up. I'm curious, now that each of you has a few months -- weeks to months at your respective roles, what kind of tools you have to understand market share trends. And with that in mind, as you entered this meeting with a nice revenue be -- versus what the Street was anticipating, how much of the acceleration, if you will, do you think was a function of improvement in the market, I guess, from a geographically adjusted basis versus the efficacy of some of the efforts that you've spoken about tonight?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we have the industry-related market share tools that are out there. We do use those. I wish we had more, but I use what's available. So we see that once a period. I see it Wednesday this week for the purposes of the most recent period,
componenttext: Well, first of all, we have the industry-related market share tools that are out there. We do use those. I wish we had more, but I use what's available. So we see that once a period. I see it Wednesday this week for the purposes of the most recent period, and we've been watching it very closely. And we watch it by geography, we watch it by category, all of the things that you would expect there. And we have seen, I would say, relatively uniform improvement on it. I mean, you've got pluses and minuses as you always will, but we've seen the sequential improvement come fairly uniformly. Share, yes.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: We got a follow-up here from Chris.
componenttext: We got a follow-up here from Chris.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris Horvers, JPMorgan, with a follow-up. So understand you don't want to share a lot of details on sort of what the supply chain looks like in the vision. But to give us a sense of what you're dealing with and I guess how much low-hanging fruit or how m
componenttext: Chris Horvers, JPMorgan, with a follow-up. So understand you don't want to share a lot of details on sort of what the supply chain looks like in the vision. But to give us a sense of what you're dealing with and I guess how much low-hanging fruit or how much hard work is ahead, can you talk about what the experience was in the northeast and some of the DCs that went to daily delivery, what you had -- what you did to unwind them and what it looks like now in those DCs?

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question, Chris. I mean, we went -- I went up there fairly early on because we were really struggling. I think May, something like that, May or June, I went to a couple of the facilities we have up there. What we did was we tried to impose a bit of
componenttext: Great question, Chris. I mean, we went -- I went up there fairly early on because we were really struggling. I think May, something like that, May or June, I went to a couple of the facilities we have up there. What we did was we tried to impose a bit of a cookie-cutter approach to those distribution centers, and they really weren't engineered to do it. We had more stores than we should have assigned to them at a delivery frequency that was very difficult for them to execute flawlessly, and that created a very chaotic environment in the distribution center. We weren't able to fill orders properly. There was accuracy issues. Yes, we were delivering 5x to the stores. But if you asked the general managers of those stores, they would have said, "Please, stop doing this because we were just -- it was a bit of a Lucy Show type thing going on. We just had stuff coming in and out, in and out, and we weren't getting the right part in the right place at the right time." So we essentially unwound that. We went to 3x in those distribution centers. We got into a much better cadence with the stores. We executed our first one in August, okay? Then we went in September in the second one. We've now done all of them. So there's transition cost that we've incurred in the last couple of -- in the third quarter and will incur in the fourth quarter, by the way, as you move to this new system. And we're seeing much better fill rates, like significantly better, much better accuracy and the general managers are much happier and they're selling more. So it just goes back to the customer wants the right part in the right place at the right time. The customer doesn't say, "Hello. Have you got 5x?" They say, "Have you got the right part?" And when we're able to fulfill that part regardless of how we got it there, that's what they're looking for. So I was in both of those facilities in, what's this, October. I was in there in October. Totally different place. There's not stuff all over the place. We've got clean house. I can see down the aisles. It's kind of important to me in a distribution center. I don't want to see stuff laying on the loading docks. I mean, I give -- tip my hat to the teams in those DCs because they've really worked at it very hard and as a result, our customers are much happier.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a follow-up from Michael.
componenttext: We have a follow-up from Michael.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, you mentioned the $500 million savings that you're going to achieve over the next 5 years is not going to be customer-facing. Can you give us more detail on the noncustomer-facing activities that are inefficient at this point? Is it mostly supply cha
componenttext: Tom, you mentioned the $500 million savings that you're going to achieve over the next 5 years is not going to be customer-facing. Can you give us more detail on the noncustomer-facing activities that are inefficient at this point? Is it mostly supply chain? Is it corporate? I think helping to at least provide a little more detail will help bridge the expectations there.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, I call it zero-based budgeting, Michael, and I do have some experience with that. I love it. It's a terrific opportunity to really standardize how costs are managed across the organization, and I would consider what we have in th
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, I call it zero-based budgeting, Michael, and I do have some experience with that. I love it. It's a terrific opportunity to really standardize how costs are managed across the organization, and I would consider what we have in there a AAA bond. It's really about getting horizontal views of all of the costs that you have across the enterprise as opposed to each cost center manager managing their costs in more of a vertical fashion and us saying, "Gee, can you do better?" It isn't a do better exercise. It's a change the physics exercise. We're not managing those costs the same way anymore. We're asking people to look at the cost in ways that have -- they haven't been looked at before. So those costs, we've got a very clear idea. Tom is running the control tower. We're very clear on where those costs are coming out. They're all -- they're across the P&L, Michael, so I can't call out specific things. They're really throughout the entire P&L. The supply chain obviously is a big area of opportunity. I mean, we just talked about one here: 5x to 3x. You deliver parts 3 times a week instead of 5 times a week. It costs less. And unless you have a really good effectiveness reason for doing it, which we didn't in that case, when we go from 5x to 3x, we save a lot of money. So we're going to continue to look for those types of opportunities, but that -- it's those types of things where, as I said earlier, the cost is coming out. It's not volume dependent to revenue dependent.

Like, what additional types -- I'd imagine Worldpac is not serving too many Audis and BMWs and probably doing more like Hyundais. I mean, just talk about the SKU mix and how it all fits together.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so again, we look at it market by market, looking at the VIOs, vehicles in operation, there and we're seeing a good mix of all makes, all models at the store level. And importantly, because many of the stores have access to the Worldpac assortment, w
componenttext: Yes, so again, we look at it market by market, looking at the VIOs, vehicles in operation, there and we're seeing a good mix of all makes, all models at the store level. And importantly, because many of the stores have access to the Worldpac assortment, we're measuring all of that activity and then basically working with the merchandising team to push those parts closer to the store, so that it will get it closer to the customer without having to have that extra touch. And so we're seeing, again, a good cross-section of parts there, mostly Asian versus high-end European, which, of course, is a Worldpac. But I would say for the most part, domestic, Asian and certainly some European Volkswagen, some Audi and so forth. But this is a good mix. But importantly, when you go to the market there, we're going to the customer with the answer that we have all of them -- all makes, all models across the entire enterprise and we're bringing that closer to the customer. So as that develops and evolves, we'll continue to build the inventory to support that activity market by market, capturing all the lookups and on the online, which we do at Worldpac today, and certainly capture all the call-ins as well. So that's going to be dynamic, dynamic inventory. Whatever the calls are out there for the customer development side, we're going to have the part closer to the customer.

headline: Advance Auto Parts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I really appreciate everybody coming this evening and the interest you have in our business. I'd just wrap it up by saying we absolutely believe that AAP is a very compelling investment opportunity. The industry is performing well. We're in a com
componenttext: Okay. So I really appreciate everybody coming this evening and the interest you have in our business. I'd just wrap it up by saying we absolutely believe that AAP is a very compelling investment opportunity. The industry is performing well. We're in a compelling market position. We feel there's a tremendous opportunity for us to drive growth and margin expansion. I think you've seen that the team is executing a pretty focused agenda going forward. We're aligned around the plan. So big opportunity to drive substantial shareholder value, and that's our commitment to you. So thanks for coming tonight.
